metadata.sermon_title: Easter / Second Sunday of Easter / Third Sunday of Easter
metadata.sermon_start_end: The symbolism of night and darkness pervades the Gospel of John. At the very beginning we hear the proclamation that the light of the incarnate Word of God comes to shine in the darkness (1:5). Repeatedly in this gospel, Jesus teaches that he brings light to the world [...] Open, we pray thee, the eyes of our faith, that we may behold him in all his redeeming work; through the same thy Son Jesus Christ our Lord, who liveth and reigneth with thee, in the unity of the Holy Spirit, one God, now and for ever.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon series follows specific pericopes. However, it often drifts into general Johannine themes (light/darkness) or cross-references (Luke, Genesis, 1 Cor) rather than mining the 'nowhere else' quality of the specific text. The Job sermon is stronger in identifying the specific 'strangeness' of God's non-answer.
quotes: The symbolism of night and darkness pervades the Gospel of John.
In the words of Jesus from Luke’s Gospel...
As Saint Paul says, the first man, Adam, was 'a man of dust'
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus more on the unique narrative details of the specific pericope (e.g., the specific arrangement of the linen cloths in John 20) rather than using them as springboards for general systematic themes.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is an awareness of context (Jewish burial customs, the Greek Styx, modern translations of Job), but it remains at a surface level. The 'requirement' of Hebrew and Greek knowledge is not visibly active in the exposition of the text's mechanics.
quotes: ...as is the burial custom of the Jews
The mythology of the Greeks and Romans is by no means wrong here
One respected modern translator puts it this way...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate deeper exegetical insights that arise from the original languages to show why the text says what it says, specifically regarding the 'whirlwind' in Job or the 'touching' in John.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: Application is concrete and avoids mere 'general truths.' The use of the Piedmont tornado and the friend's grief over ashes provides the 'psychological help' Dekker mentions. It addresses the zeitgeist of doubt and loss effectively.
quotes: In 1994, a church in Piedmont, Alabama, was destroyed by a tornado...
I have a dear friend whose daughter died tragically. The rest of the family were determined to scatter the ashes...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application doesn't just illustrate the text but is 'expounded' by it. The tornado example is strong but risks becoming a general 'problem of evil' discussion.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon moves back and forth between the biblical narrative and modern experience. It avoids the '15 min exposition / 5 min application' trap, though the transitions are sometimes abrupt.
quotes: Have you buried someone? If you haven’t, you will.
Thomas stands for all of us here. We haven’t seen the risen Lord.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Try to draw the hearer into the text's world more seamlessly so that the 'present of revelation' occurs within the biblical story itself.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Strong adherence to this thesis. The sermon dwells extensively on 'misery' (darkness, death, dust) without rushing to a cheap 'redemption.' It respects the 'moral duty' to remain with misery where the text demands it.
quotes: This is the night of the end of human hope.
I will be quiet, comforted that I am dust.
The realm of darkness appears to be victorious.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ensure 'gratitude' is more clearly developed as a response to the 'Who' of revelation, rather than just a cessation of complaint.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are present but muted. The sermon mentions the choice between a 'man-made god' and the 'God who is really God,' but the existential weight of being 'lost' is less sharp than Dekker requires.
quotes: We have a real choice. We can choose a god who suits us...
Those traditions will disappear... because they take neither man nor God seriously.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Thematically sharpen the consequence of choosing the 'domesticated god.' Make the 'lostness' of the broad way more explicit.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon emphasizes the 'two natures' (God entering pain) and points to salvation outside the self. The Job sermon successfully links the Old Testament longing to the Christological answer.
quotes: The Son of God, by his own permission, has been given over to the realm of night.
God has entered our pain and been wounded by it... raised triumphant.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: In the Job sermon, ensure the transition to Christ doesn't feel like a 'dogmatic addition' but an organic fulfillment of Job's specific 'nowhere else' cry.

8_depth_and_length.findings: As a single unit, the text covers three Sundays. Individually, each section appears to be roughly 700-800 words, which at 100 words/min is only 7-8 minutes. This fails Dekker's 20-minute minimum for 'breadth.'
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the 'breadth' of the exposition. To reach 20 minutes, the preacher must dwell longer on the biblical text's specificities and the complexities of the humanities.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon series is theologically robust and avoids the 'liberal' trap of generalities, yet it falls short of Dekker's formal requirements regarding length and exegetical depth. It excels in the 'misery' category, taking human suffering and the 'night' of death with the required Barthian seriousness. However, the brevity of the individual segments prevents the 'depth through breadth' that Dekker demands.
strengths: Concrete application via the Piedmont tornado and personal grief narratives.
Strong emphasis on the 'otherness' of God in the Job section.
Refusal to offer 'pious platitudes' or easy answers to misery.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (well under the 20-minute threshold per sermon).
Lack of visible engagement with original languages (Hebrew/Greek).
The 'two ways' (the possibility of being lost) could be more sharply articulated.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a substantively strong proclamation that understands the 'One Lord' and 'Three Parts,' but formally it is a 'short speech' rather than a 'sermon' by Dekker's definition. It lacks the breadth required for true homiletical depth.
